questions.text: An 11-year-old Chandu is referred to neurology by his doctor for frequent sniffing despite a lack of congestion or seasonal allergies. For the last year, he frequently sniffed for no reason and began to flick his finger throughout the day. On examination, you appreciate the noted mannerisms, and also note frequent throat clearing, echolalia and palilalia. The patient reports that he feels anxious unless he performs the action and has a sense of relief after performing the action. They are also suppressible. Which of the following is a comorbidity of this condition?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

All of the above The boy has very typical findings of Tourette syndrome and all of the above comorbidities are seen with taurette’s syndrome. The criteria of Diagnosis of taurette’s syndrome is fulfilled- Multiple motor tics(sniffing,flicking finger) accompanied by vocal tics(echolalia,palilalia) . Also the patient is getting an irresistible urge to perform an action and relief after performing the action.

Highyeild:

Tourette’s syndrome (TS)- It is a neurobehavioral disorder It predominantly affects males Diagnosis criteria- Multiple motor tics often accompanied by vocalizations (phonic tics) . Patients characteristically can voluntarily suppress tics for short periods of time, but then experience an irresistible urge to express them. Tics vary in intensity and may be absent for days or weeks only to recur, occasionally in a different pattern. Tics tend to present between ages 2 and 15 years (mean 7 years) and often lessen or even disappear in adulthood, particularly in males. Associated behavioral disturbances Anxiety Depression attention deficit hyperactivity disorder obsessive-compulsive disorder personality disorders self-destructive behaviors difficulties in school impaired interpersonal relationships Treatment Tetrabenazine Topiramate Antidopaminergic medications for the motor symptoms.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A is better than options B, C, and D

Extraedge:

TICS Non-rhythmic, voluntary dyskinesia. Occurs as separate entity GILLES DE LA TOURETTE(component) <18 years of age Male>female Types Simple Complex Vocal tics Palilalia Echolalia Coprolalia Motor tics Echopraxia Copropraxia Treatment of tics Alpha agonists Guanfacine Clonidine Antipsychotic

questions.text: A 43-year-old man presents to the hospital complaining of periodic involuntary head turning and head fixation to the right side. Physical examination reveals a hypertrophied left sternocleidomastoid muscle. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Dystonia This patient suffers from torticollis , focal dystonia of the sternocleidomastoid muscle . Dystonia is defined as sustained muscle contraction resulting in twisting, repetitive movements, or abnormal postures. It may be focal (affecting only one muscle) or diffuse .

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Essential tremor presents with repeating, rhythmic movement. Option: B. Athetosis presents with involuntary, slow, writhing Option: D. Chorea -presents with involuntary, rapid, distal,rapid-jerky movements.

questions.text: A patient with essential tremor is being managed on Propranolol (20–120 mg daily, given in divided doses). The patient is concerned about the outcomes. Which of the following tremor is often refractory to treatment?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Head tremor Hand tremor tends to be most improved, while head tremor is often refractory.

Highyeild:

TREMORS- Repeating, a rhythmic movement disorder. Resting tremor Decrease on action-Parkinson’s disease Increase on action-Red nucleus lesion(Rubral tremor) Action tremor Terminal /Intentional tremor-Cerebellar lesion Postural tremors- Essential tremor Thyrotoxicosis Treatment of Tremors- Hand tremor tends to be most improved, while head tremor is often refractory. Many cases are mild , do not cause any functional impairment, and require no treatment other than reassurance. Occasionally, tremors can be severe and interfere with eating, writing, and activities of daily living. This is more likely to occur as the patient ages and is often associated with a reduction in tremor frequency. Drug therapy Beta Blockers Contraindication Bradycardia Asthma Primidone Other drugs Gabapentin Topiramate Botulinum toxin injections for limb or voice tremor Side effect-muscle weakness. Surgical therapies targeting the ventral-intermediate (VIM) nucleus of the thalamus for severe cases drug-resistant cases. focal ultrasound shown to be an effective therapy against tremors in Essential Tremor.

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option:A. Hand tremor - tends to be most improved. Option:C. Voice tremor- Usually improved. Option:D. Lower limb tremor- Usually improved.

questions.text: Which of the following attenuates the Dystonia brought out by voluntary movements?
questions.correct_answer: C. Touching the affected body part
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Touching the affected body part Attenuated by relaxation and sensory tricks such as touching the affected body part.

Highyeild:

Dystonia- Dystonia is a movement disorder characterized by sustained or intermittent muscle contractions of agonist/antagonist muscles causing abnormal, often repetitive movements and postures . Dystonia is often by voluntary action and associated with overflow muscle activation. Dystonia is often initiated or worsened by voluntary movements ( action dystonia ) and can extend to involve other muscle groups and body regions not required for the intended action ( overflow dystonia ). Aggravated by Stress Fatigue Attenuated by Relaxation Sensory tricks Touching the affected body part ( geste antagoniste) .

questions.text: All are true about Meige’s syndrome EXCEPT?

options.label: A
options.text: Predominantly affects Men aged less than 50 years

options.label: B
options.text: Contractions of muscles of the lower face

questions.correct_answer: A. Predominantly affects Men aged less than 50 years
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Predominantly affects Men aged less than 50 years Meige’s syndrome is a combination of Oromandibular dystonia( contractions of muscles of the lower face, lips, tongue, and jaw (opening or closing). and blepharospasm that predominantly affects women aged >60 years.

Highyeild:

Dystonia- Dystonia is defined as sustained muscle contraction resulting in twisting, repetitive movements, or abnormal postures . It may be focal (affecting only one muscle) or diffuse . ISOLATED DYSTONIAS A)Focal, Multifocal, and Segmental Dystonia Onset-Adulthood The major clinical phenotypes are as follows: Cervical dystonia - (most common) dystonic contractions of neck muscles causing the head to deviate to one side ( laterocollis) , twist ( torticollis ), move in a forward direction (anterocollis) , or move in a backward direction ( retrocollis ). Muscle contractions can be painful and occasionally can be complicated by a secondary cervical radiculopathy. Blepharospasm- dystonic contractions of the eyelids with increased blinking that can interfere with reading, watching television, working on a computer, and driving. This can sometimes be severe enough to cause functional blindness. Oromandibular dystonia (OMD) -contractions of muscles of the lower face, lips, tongue, and jaw (opening or closing). Meige’s syndrome is a combination of OMD and blepharospasm that predominantly affects women aged >60 years . Spasmodic dysphonia- dystonic contractions of the vocal cords during phonation, causing impaired speech. Most cases affect the adductor muscles and cause speech to have a choking or strained quality. Less commonly, the abductors are affected, leading to speech with a breathy or whispering quality. Limb dystonias -these can be present in either arms or legs and are often brought out by task-specific activities such as handwriting (writer’s cramp ), playing a musical instrument ( musician’s cramp ), or putting in golf (the yips).

Random:

Options B, C, and D are correct.

questions.text: Which is the most common systemic disorder that is associated with chorea?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Systemic lupus erythematosus Systemic lupus erythematosus is the most common systemic disorder that is associated with chorea.

Highyeild:

Chorea is characterized by non-rhythmic, involuntary, rapid, distal, rapid jerky movements. Associations of chorea- genetic mutations Huntington’s disease childhood-onset chorea Chorea-acanthocytosis (neuroacanthocytosis) Kell blood group antigens (McLeod syndrome) Infections Syndenham’s chorea herpes simplex virus encephalitis HIV disease , degenerative disorders vascular diseases hypo- and hyperglycemia. association with pregnancy (chorea gravidarum) paraneoplastic syndromes associated with anti-CRMP-5 or anti-Hu antibodies. systemic disorder Systemic lupus erythematosus(a most common cause of Chorea in systemic disorder) Hyperthyroidism autoimmune disorders Sjögren’s syndrome polycythemia vera Following open-heart surgery in the pediatric population Medications treatment with sex hormones Anticonvulsants Cocaine CNS stimulants Lithium chronic levodopa The chorea can last for days to years. Treatment Generally self-limiting Severe chorea dopamine-blocking agents valproic acid carbamazepine

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Options A, B, and D are associations of chorea but Less common than SLE(Systemic lupus erythematosus ).

Extraedge:

Sydenham’s chorea (originally called St. Vitus’ dance) more common in females typically seen in childhood (5–15 years). It often develops in association with prior exposure to group A streptococcal infection(rheumatic fever) autoimmune . characterized by acute onset of choreiform movements behavioral disturbances.

questions.text: All are true about Ballismus EXCEPT?

options.label: A
options.text: A violent form of choreiform movement composed of wild, flinging, large-amplitude movements

options.label: B
options.text: The movements may be so severe as to cause death in extreme cases

questions.correct_answer: D. Doesn’t respond to Dopamine-blocking drugs
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Doesn’t respond to Dopamine-blocking drugs Dopamine-blocking drugs can be very helpful in Ballismus.

Highyeild:

BALLISM/HEMIBALLISMUS Ballism is a violent form of choreiform movement composed of wild, flinging, large-amplitude movements, most frequently affecting proximal limb muscles on one side of the body ( hemiballism) . The movements may affect only one limb ( monoballism ) both upper or lower limbs ( parallelism ). The movements may be so severe as to cause Exhaustion Dehydration Local injury Death (extreme cases). Causes- Partial lesion (infarct/hemorrhage) in the subthalamic nucleus(most common cause) Lesion in the putamen, thalamus, or parietal cortex. With other paroxysmal dyskinesias Surgically induced lesions and Deep brain stimulation of the subthalamic nucleus (STN-DBS) in Parkinson's Disease patients are usually not associated with hemiballismus Treatment- Usually self-limiting Dopamine-blocking drugs. In extreme cases- Pallidotomy DBS of the GPi (Deep Brain Stimulation of Globus Pallidus Internus)

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Options A, B, and C are true about Ballismus.

questions.text: In which of the following Paroxysmal dyskinesias, attacks are NOT induced by movement?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Paroxysmal non-kinesigenic dyskinesia Paroxysmal dyskinesia is a group of rare disorders characterized by episodic, brief involuntary movements . In paroxysmal non -kinesigenic dyskinesia (PNKD) , the attacks are not induced by movement.

Highyeild:

PAROXYSMAL DYSKINESIAS- Paroxysmal dyskinesias are a group of rare disorders characterized by episodic, brief involuntary movements that can manifest as various types of hyperkinetic movements , including chorea , dystonia , tremor , myoclonus , and ballism. There are three main types- Paroxysmal kinesigenic dyskinesia (PKD) - involuntary movements are triggered by sudden movement. Paroxysmal nonkinesigenic dyskinesias (PNKD) -attacks are not induced by movement. Paroxysmal exertion induced dyskinesia (PED) (Rare)- attacks are induced by prolonged exercise.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Options A and C are induced by movement. Option D is incorrect.

questions.text: All of the following represent core symptoms of Restless Legs Syndrome for diagnosis EXCEPT?

options.label: A
options.text: An urge to move the legs usually accompanied by an unpleasant sensation in the legs

options.label: C
options.text: Partial or complete relief by movement

options.label: D
options.text: Worsening during the evening or night

questions.correct_answer: B. Symptoms that relieves with rest
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Symptoms that relieves with rest Symptoms begin or worsen with rest but are NOT relieved in Restless leg syndrome.

Highyeild:

Restless legs syndrome (RLS) The four core symptoms required for diagnosis are as follows- An urge to move the legs usually caused or accompanied by an unpleasant sensation in the legs Symptoms that begin or worsen with rest Partial or complete relief by movement Worsening during the evening or night Symptoms- Unpleasant sensation, creepy-crawly feeling, paresthesia, or burning. Most commonly begin in the legs but can spread to/ begin in the upper limbs. RLS is associated with periodic leg movements (PLMs) during sleep and occasionally while awake. The restlessness and PLMs are a major cause of sleep disturbance , leading to poor-quality sleep and daytime sleepiness. Primary Restless legs syndrome (RLS) - Strong genetic component No causative gene has been identified. Secondary Restless legs syndrome (RLS) - may be associated with Pregnancy Anemia ferritin deficiency renal failure peripheral Tremor, Chorea, and Other Movement Disorders . Pathogenesis - Peripheral or central disordered dopamine function ,possibly in association with an abnormality of iron metabolism . Diagnosis- clinical grounds Supported by Polysomnography Demonstration of PLMs(periodic leg movements ) Neurologic examination-normal. Secondary causes of RLS should be excluded Ferritin levels Glucose Renal function test.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Options A, C, and D are core features of restless leg syndrome.

Extraedge:

Treatment of Restless legs syndrome (RLS)- Mild cases Improve sleep hygiene Drug of choice - Gabapentin Pramipexole Ropinirole Rotigotine Treatment of underlying anemia.
